text: Ye, young men of good family, mind, for mercy's sake towards all beings, that it is a very difficult task to which the Chief urges you.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: One might expound many thousands of Sûtras, like to the sands of the Ganges, without overmuch difficulty.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: One who after grasping the Sumeru in the fist were to hurl it a distance of kotis of fields, would do nothing very difficult.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: Nor would it be so very difficult if one could shake this whole universe by the thumb to hurl it a distance of kotis of fields.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: Nor would one who, after taking stand on the limit of the existing world, were to expound the law and thousands of other Sûtras, do something so very difficult.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: But to keep and preach this Sûtra in the dreadful period succeeding the extinction of the Chief of the world, that is difficult.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: To throw down the totality of ether-element after compressing it in one fist, and to leave it behind after having thrown it away, is not difficult.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: But to copy a Sûtra like this in the period after my extinction, that is difficult.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: To collect the whole earth-element at a nail's end, cast it away, and then walk off to the Brahma-world,

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: Is not difficult, nor would it require a strength surpassing everybody's strength to do this work of difficulty.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: Something more difficult than that will he do who in the last days after my extinction shall pronounce this Sûtra, were it but a single moment.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: It will not be difficult for him to walk in the midst of the conflagration at the (time of the) end of the world, even if he carries with him a load of hay.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: More difficult it will be to keep this Sûtra after my extinction and teach it to a single creature.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: One may keep the eighty-four thousand divisions of the law and expound them, with the instructions and such as they have been set forth, to kotis of living beings;

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: This is not so difficult; nor is it, to train at the present time monks, and confirm my disciples in the five parts of transcendent knowledge.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: But more difficult is it to keep this Satra, believe in it, adhere to it, or expound it again and again.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: Even he who confirms many thousands of kotis of Arhats, blest with the possession of the six transcendent faculties (Abhigñâs), like sands of the Ganges,

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: Performs something not so difficult by far as the excellent man does who after my extinction shall keep my sublime law.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: I have often, in thousands of worlds, preached the law, and to-day also I preach it with the view that Buddha-knowledge may be obtained.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: This Sûtra is declared the principal of all Sûtras; he who keeps in his memory this Stitra, keeps the body of the Gina.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: Speak, O young men of good family, while the Tathâgata is (still) in your presence, who amongst you is to exert himself in later times to keep the Sûtra.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: Not only I myself shall be pleased, but the Lords of the world in general, if one would keep for a moment this Sûtra so difficult to keep.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: Such a one shall ever be praised by all the Lords of the world, famed as an eminent hero, and ouick in arrivinLy at transcendent wisdom.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: He shall be entrusted with the leadership amongst the sons of the Tathâgatas, he who, after having reached the stage of meekness, shall keep this Sûtra.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: He shall be the eye of the world, including gods and men, who shall speak this Sûtra after the extinction of the Chief of men.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: He is to be venerated by all beings, the wise man who in the last times shall preach this Sûtra (were it but) a single moment.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: I have a remembrance of past ages when I was Dhârmika, the King of the Law, and exercised the royal sway for duty's sake, not for love's sake, in the interest of the best laws.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: I let go out in all directions this proclamation: I will become a servant to him who shall explain Dharma. At that time there was a far-seeing Sage, a revealer of the Sûtra called the True Law.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: He said to me: If thou wish to know Dharma, become my servant; then I will explain it to thee. As I heard these words I rejoiced and carefully performed such work as a servant ought to do.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: I never felt any bodily nor mental weariness since I had become a servant for the sake of the true law. I did my best for real truth's sake, not with a view to win honour or enjoy pleasure.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: That king meanwhile, strenuously and without engaging in other pursuits, roamed in every direction during thousands of kotis of complete Æons without being able to obtain the Sûtra called Dharma.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: O thou blessed one, who from thy wisdom art called the Sage, by whose power is it that thou to-day (or now) hast educated those innumerable beings? Tell it me upon my question, O thou god amongst men.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: What law hast thou preached, or what Sûtra, in showing the path of enlightenment, so that those who are there with you have conceived the idea of enlightenment? that, once having gained a safe ford', they have been decisively established in omniscience?

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: Spotless, bright, and of unfathomable light is that ethereal body, adorned with the thirty-two characteristic signs, pervading space in all directions.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: He is possessed of the secondary marks and praised by every being, and accessible to all, like an open market-place.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: I have obtained enlightenment according to my wish; the Tathâgata can bear witness to it; I will extensively reveal the law that releases from sufferance.

title: APPARITION OF A STÛPA.
text: the rank of Brahma; 2. the rank of Indra; 3. the rank of a chief guardian of the four quarters; 4. the rank of Kakravartin; 5. the rank of a Bodhisattva incapable of sliding back .

title: EXERTION.
text: O Lord, thou art the trainer, thou art the leader; thou art the master of the world, including the gods; thou art the giver of comfort, thou who art worshipped by men and gods. Now, indeed, we feel satisfied.

title: EXERTION.
text: Be at ease, O Lord. After thy complete extinction, in the horrible last period of the world, we will proclaim this sublime Sûtra.

title: EXERTION.
text: We will suffer, patiently endure, O Lord, the injuries, threats, blows and threats with sticks at the hands of foolish men.

title: EXERTION.
text: At that dreadful last epoch men will be malign, crooked, wicked, dull, conceited, fancying to have come to the limit when they have not.

title: EXERTION.
text: 'We do not care but to live in the wilderness and wear a patched cloth; we lead a frugal life;' so will they speak to the ignorant.

title: EXERTION.
text: And persons greedily attached to enjoyments will preach the law to laymen and be honoured as if they possessed the six transcendent qualities.

title: EXERTION.
text: Cruel-minded and wicked men, only occupied with household cares, will enter our retreat in the forest and become our calumniators.

title: EXERTION.
text: The Tîrthikas, themselves bent on profit and honour, will say of us that we are so, and-shame on such monks!-they will preach their own fictions.

title: EXERTION.
text: Prompted by greed of profit and honour they will compose Sûtras of their own invention and then, in the midst of the assembly, accuse us of plagiarism.

title: EXERTION.
text: To kings, princes, king's peers, as well as to Brahmans and commoners, and to monks of other confessions,

title: EXERTION.
text: They will speak evil of us and propagate the Tîrtha-doctrine. We will endure all that out of reverence for the great Seers.

title: EXERTION.
text: And those fools who will not listen to us, shall (sooner or later) become enlightened, and therefore will we forbear to the last.

title: EXERTION.
text: In that dreadful, most terrible period of frightful general revolution will many fiendish monks stand up as our revilers.

title: EXERTION.
text: Out of respect for the Chief of the world we will bear it, however difficult it be; girded with the girdle of forbearance will I proclaim this Sûtra.

title: EXERTION.
text: I do not care for my body or life, O Lord, but as keepers of thine entrusted deposit we care for enlightenment.

title: EXERTION.
text: The Lord himself knows that in the last pericd there are (to be) wicked monks who do not understand mysterious speech.

title: EXERTION.
text: One will have to bear frowning looks, repeated disavowal (or concealment), expulsion from the monasteries, many and manifold abuses.

title: EXERTION.
text: Yet mindful of the command of the Lord of the world we will in the last period undauntedly proclaim this Sûtra in the midst of the congregation.

title: EXERTION.
text: We will visit towns and villages everywhere, and transmit to those who care for it thine entrusted deposit, O Lord.

title: EXERTION.
text: O Chief of the world, we will deliver thy message; be at ease then, tranquil and quiet, great Seer.

title: EXERTION.
text: Light of the world, thou knowest the disposition of all who have flocked hither from every direction, (and thou knowest that) we speak a word of truth.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: The Bodhisattva who, undaunted and unabashed, wishes to set forth this Sûtra in the dreadful period hereafter,

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: Must keep to his course (of duty) and proper sphere; he must be retired and pure, constantly avoid intercourse with kings and princes.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: Nor should he keep up intercourse with king's servants, nor with Kândâlas, jugglers, and Tîrthikas in general.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: He ought not to court conceited men, but catechise such as keep to the religion. He must also avoid such monks as follow the precepts of the Arhat [of the Gainas], and immoral men.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: He must be constant in avoiding a nun who is fond of banter and chatter; he must also avoid notoriously loose female lay devotees.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: He should shun any intercourse with such female lay devotees as seek their highest happiness in this transient world. This is called the proper conduct of a Bodhisattva.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: But when one comes to him to question him about the law for the sake of superior enlightenment, he should, at any time, speak freely, always firm and undaunted.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: He should have no intercourse with women and hermaphrodites; he should also shun the young wives and girls in families.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: He must never address them to ask after their health. He must also avoid intercourse with vendors of pork and mutton.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: With any persons who slay animals of various kind for the sake of profit, and with such as sell meat he should avoid having any intercourse.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: He must shun the society of whoremongers, players, musicians, wrestlers, and other people of that sort.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: He should not frequent whores, nor other sensual persons; he must avoid any exchange of civility with them.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: And when the sage has to preach for a woman, he should not enter into an apartment with her alone, nor stay to banter.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: When he has often to enter a village in quest of food, he must have another monk with him or constantly think of the Buddha.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: Herewith have I shown the first sphere of proper conduct. Wise are they who, keeping this Sqtra in memory, live according to it.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: And when one observes no law at all, low, superior or mean, composed or uncomposed, real or not real;

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: When the wise man does not remark, 'This is a woman,' nor marks,'This is a man;' when in searching he finds no laws (or things), because they have never existed;

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: This is called the observance of the Bodhisattvas in general. Now listen to me when I set forth what should be their proper sphere.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: All laws (i.e. the laws, the things) have been declared to be non-existing, not appearing, not produced, void, immovable, everlasting; this is called the proper sphere of the wise.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: They have been divided into existing and non-existing, real and unreal, by those who had wrong notions; other laws also, of permanency, of being produced, of birth from something already produced, are wrongly assumed.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: Let (the Bodhisattva) be concentrated in mind, attentive, ever firm as the peak of Mount Sumeru, and in such a state (of mind) look upon all laws (and things) as having the nature of space [i.e. as being void],

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: Permanently equal to space, without essence, immovable, without substantiality. These, indeed, are the laws, all and for ever. This is called the proper sphere of the wise.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: The monk observing this rule of conduct given by me may, after my extinction, promulgate this Sûtra in the world, and shall feel no depression.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: Let the sage first, for some time, coerce his thoughts, exercise meditation with complete absorption, and correctly perform all that is required for attaining spiritual insight, and then, after rising (from his pious meditation), preach with unquailing mind.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: The kings of this earth and the princes who listen to the law protect him. Others also, both laymen (or burghers) and Brahmans, will be found together in his congregation.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: The wise man is always at ease, and in that state he preaches the law, seated on an elevated pulpit which has been prepared for him on a clean and pretty spot.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: He puts on a clean, nice, red robe, dyed with good colours, and a black woollen garment and a long undergarment;

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: Having duly washed his feet and rubbed his head and face with smooth ointments, he ascends the pulpit, which is provided with a footbank and covered with pieces of fine cloth of various sorts, and sits down.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: When he is thus seated on the preacher's pulpit and all who have gathered round him are attentive, he proceeds to deliver many discourses, pleasing by variety, before monks and nuns,

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: Before male and female lay devotees, kings and princes. The wise man always (takes care to) deliver a sermon diversified in its contents and sweet, free from invidiousness.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: If occasionally he is asked some question, even after he has commenced, he will explain the matter anew in regular order, and he will explain it in such away that his hearers gain enlightenment.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: The wise man is indefatigable; not even the thought of fatigue will rise in him; he knows no listlessness, and so displays to the assembly the strength of charity.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: Day and night the wise man preaches this sublime law with myriads of kotis of illustrations; he edifies and satisfies his audience without ever requiring anything.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: Solid food, soft food, nourishment and drink, cloth, couches, robes, medicaments for the sick, all this does not occupy his thoughts, nor does he want anything from the congregation.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: On the contrary, the wise man is always thinking: How can I and these beings become Buddhas? I will preach this true law, upon which the happiness of all beings depends, for the benefit of the world.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: The monk who, after my extinction, shall preach in this way, without envy, shall not meet with trouble, impediment, grief or despondency.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: Nobody shall frighten him, beat or blame him; never shall he be driven away, because he is firm in the strength of forbearance.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: The wise man who is peaceful, so disposed as I have just said, possesses hundreds of kotis of advantages, so many that one would not be able to enumerate them in hundreds of Æons.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: The wise man, the preacher, who wishes to expound this Sûtra must absolutely renounce falsehood, pride, calumny, and envy.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: He should never speak a disparaging word of anybody; never engage in a dispute on religious belief; never say to such as are guilty of shortcomings, You will not obtain superior knowledge.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: He is always sincere, mild, forbearing; (as) a (true) son of Sugata he will repeatedly preach the law without any feeling of vexation.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: 'The Bodhisattvas in all directions of space, who out of compassion for creatures are moving in the world, are my teachers;' (thus thinking) the wise man respects them as his masters.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: Cherishing the memory of the Buddhas, the supreme amongst men, he will always feel towards them as if they were his fathers, and by forsaking all idea of pride he will escape hindrance.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: The wise man who has heard this law, should be constant in observing it. If he earnestly strives after a peaceful life, kotis of beings will surely protect him.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: Always displaying the strength of charity, always filled with compassion for all creatures, expounding this law, the Sugatas have approved this exalted Sûtra.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: The laymen, as well as the mendicant friars, and the Bodhisattvas who shall live at the end of time, must all show the strength of charity, lest those who hear the law reject it.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: But I, when I shall have reached enlightenment and be established in Tathâgataship, will initiate (others), and after having initiated disciples preach everywhere this superior enlightenment.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: It is (a case) like that of a king, ruler of armies, who gives to his soldiers various things, gold, elephants, horses, cars, foot soldiers; he also gives towns and villages, in token of his contentment.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: In his satisfaction he gives to some hand-ornaments, silver and gold thread; pearls, gems, conch-shells, stones (?), coral; he also gives slaves of various description.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: But when he is struck with the incomparable daring of one amongst the soldiers, he says: Thou. hast admirably done this; and, taking off his crown, makes him a present of the jewel.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: Likewise do I, the Buddha, the king of the law, I who have the force of patience and a large treasure of wisdom, with justice govern the whole world, benign, compassionate, and pitiful.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: And seeing how the creatures are in trouble, I pronounce thousands of kotis of Sûtrântas, when I perceive the heroism of those living beings who by pure-mindedness overcome the sinful inclinations of the world.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: And the king of the law, the great physician, who expounds hundreds of kotis of Paryâyas, when he recognises that creatures are strong, shows them this Sûtra, comparable to a crown jewel.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: This is the last Sûtra proclaimed in the world, the most eminent of all my Sûtras, which I have always kept and never divulged. Now I am going to make it known; listen all.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: There are four qualities to be acquired by those who at the period after my extinction desire supreme enlightenment and perform my charge. The qualities are such as follows.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: The wise man knows no vexation, trouble, sickness; the colour of his skin is not blackish; nor does he dwell in a miserable town.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: The great Sage has always a pleasant look, deserves to be honoured, as if he were the Tathâgata himself, and little angels shall constantly be his attendants.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: His body can never be hurt by weapons, poison, sticks, or clods, and the mouth of the man who utters a word of abuse against him shall be closed.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: He is a friend to all creatures in the world. He goes all over the earth as a light, dissipating the gloom of many kotis of creatures, he who keeps this Sûtra after my extinction.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: In his sleep he sees visions in the shape of Buddha; he sees monks and nuns appearing on thrones and proclaiming the many-sided law.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: He sees in his dream gods and goblins, (numerous) as the sands of the Ganges, as well as demons and Nâgas of many kinds, who lift their joined hands and to whom he expounds the eminent law.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: He sees in his dream the Tathâgata preaching the law to many kotis of beings with lovely voice, the Lord with golden colour.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: And he stands there with joined hands glorifying the Seer, the highest of men, whilst the Gina, the great physician, is expounding the law to the four classes.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: And he, glad to have heard the law, joyfully pays his worship, and after having soon reached the knowledge which never slides back, he obtains, in dream, magical spells.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: And the Lord of the world, perceiving his good intention, announces to him his destiny of becoming a leader amongst men: Young man of good family (says he), thou shalt here reach in future supreme, holy knowledge.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: Thou shalt have a large field and four classes (of hearers), even as myself, that respectfully and with joined hands shall hear from thee the vast and faultless law.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: Again he sees his own person occupied with meditating on the law in mountain caverns; and by meditating he attains the very nature of the law and, on obtaining complete absorption, sees the Gina.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: And after seeing in his dream the goldcoloured one, him who displays a hundred hallowed signs, he hears the law, whereafter he preaches it in the assembly. Such is his dream.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: And in his dream he also forsakes his whole realm, harem, and numerous kinsfolk; renouncing all pleasures he leaves home (to become an ascetic), and betakes himself to the place of the terrace of enlightenment.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: There, seated upon a throne at the foot of a tree to seek enlightenment, he will, after the lapse of seven days, arrive at the knowledge of the Tathâgatas.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: On having reached enlightenment he will rise up from that place to move forward the faultless wheel and preach the law during an inconceivable number of thousands of kotis of Æons.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: After having revealed perfect enlightenment and led many kotis of beings to perfect rest, he himself will be extinguished like a lamp when the oil is exhausted. So is that vision.

title: PEACEFUL LIFE.
text: Endless, Mañgughosha, are the advantages which constantly are his who at the end of time shall expound this Sûtra of superior enlightenment that I have perfectly explained.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: 20, 10, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1 Ganges river; of 1/2, 1/4, 1/6, 1/10, 1/20, 1/50, 1/100, 1/1000, 1/100,000, 1/10,000,000, 1/100 X 10,000,000, 1/1000 X 10,000,000, 1/100 X 1000 X 10,000,000, 1/100 X 1000 X 10,000 X 10,000,000 part of the river Ganges. Much more there were to be found of Bodhisattvas Mahâsattvas having a train of many hundred thousand myriads of kotis of Bodhisattvas; of one koli; of one hundred thousand; of one thousand; Of 500; Of 400; Of 300; Of 200; Of 100; Of 50; Of 40; Of 30; Of 20; Of 10; Of 5, 4, 3, 2. Much more there were to be found of Bodhisattvas Mahâsattvas having one follower. Much more there were to be found of Bodhisattvas Mahâsattvas standing isolated. They cannot be numbered, counted, calculated, compared, known by occult science, the Bodhisattvas Mahâsattvas who emerged from the gaps of the earth to appear in this Saha-world. And after they had successively emerged they went up to the Stûpa of precious substances which stood in the sky, where the Lord Prabhûtaratna, the extinct Tathâgata, was seated along with the Lord Sâkyamuni on the throne. Whereafter they saluted the feet of both Tathâgatas, &c., as well as the images of Tathâgatas produced by the Lord Sâkyamuni from his own body, who all together were seated on thrones at the foot of various jewel trees on every side in all directions, in different worlds. After these Bodhisattvas had many hundred thousand times saluted, and thereon circumambulated the Tathâgatas, &c., from left to right, and celebrated them with various Bodhisattva hymns, they went and kept themselves at a little distance, the joined hands stretched out to honour the Lord Sâkyamuni, the Tathâgata, &c., and the Lord Prabhûtaratna, the Tathâgata, &c.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: Does the Lord of the world, the illuminator, feel at ease? Dost thou feel free from bodily disease, O Perfect One?

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: The creatures, we hope, will be decorous, docile, performing the orders of the Lord of the world, so as to give no trouble.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: Excellent, excellent, O great Hero! we are happy to hear that those creatures are decorous, docile, well performing their duty';

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: And that they listen to thy profound knowledge, O Leader, and that after listening to it they have put trust in it and understand it.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: Here are many thousand myriads of kotis of Bodhisattvas, numberless, whom we never saw before; tell us, O supreme of men!

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: Whence and how do these mighty persons come? Whence have they come here under the form of great bodies'?

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: All are great Seers, wise and strong in memory, whose outward appearance is lovely to see; whence have they come?

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: And each of those Bodhisattvas, O Lord of the world, has an immense train, like the sands of the Ganges.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: The train of (each) glorious Bodhisattva is equal to the sands of sixty Ganges in full. All are striving after enlightenment.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: Of such heroes and mighty possessors of a troop the followers are equal to the sands of sixty Ganges.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: There are others, still more numerous, with an unlimited train, like the sands of fifty, forty, and thirty Ganges;

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: 13. Who have a train equal to the (sands of) twenty Ganges. Still more numerous are the mighty sons of Buddha, who have each a train (equal to the sands) of ten, of five Ganges. Whence, O Leader, has such an assembly flocked hither?

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: There are others who have each a train of pupils and companions equal to the sands of four, three, or two Ganges.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: There are others more numerous yet; it would be impossible to calculate their number in thousands of kotis of Æons.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: (Equal to) a half Ganges, one third, one tenth, one twentieth, is the train of those heroes, those mighty Bodhisattvas.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: There are yet others who are incalculable; it would be impossible to count them even in hundreds of kotis of Æons.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: Many more yet there are, with endless trains; they have in their attendance kotis, and kotis and again kotis, and also half kotis.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: Other great Seers again, beyond computation, very wise Bodhisattvas are seen in a respectful posture.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: They have a thousand, a hundred, or fifty attendants; in hundreds of kotis of Æons one would not be able to count them.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: The suite of (some of these) heroes consists of twenty, of ten, five, four, three, or two; those are countless.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: As to those who are walking alone and come to their rest alone, they have now flocked hither in such numbers as to be beyond computation.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: Even if one with a magic wand in his hand would try for a number of Æons equal to the sands of the Ganges to count them, he would not reach the term.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: Where do all those noble, energetic heroes, those mighty Bodhisattvas, come from?

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: Who has taught them the law (or duty)? and by whom have they been destined to enlightenment? Whose command do they accept? Whose command do they keep?

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: Bursting forth at all points of the horizon through the whole extent of the earth they emerge, those great Sages endowed with magical faculty and wisdom.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: This world on every side is being perforated, O Seer, by the wise Bodhisattvas, who at this time are emerging.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: Never before have we seen anything like this. Tell us the name of this world, O Leader.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: We have repeatedly roamed in all directions of space, but never saw these Bodhisattvas.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: We never saw a single infant of thine, and now, on a sudden, these appear to us. Tell us their history, O Seer.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: Hundreds, thousands, ten thousands of Bodhisattvas, all equally filled with curiosity, look up to the highest of men.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: Explain to us, O incomparable, great hero,who knowest no bounds, where do these heroes, these wise Bodhisattvas, come from?

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: Be attentive all, young men of good family; I am to utter an infallible word; refrain from disputing about it, O sages: the science of the Tathâgata is beyond reasoning.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: Be all steady and thoughtful; continue attentive all. To-day you will hear a law as yet unknown, the wonder of the Tathâgatas.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: Never have any doubt, ye sages, for I shall strengthen you, I am the Leader who speaketh infallible truth, and my knowledge is unlimited.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: Profound are the laws known to the Sugata, above reasoning and beyond argumentation. These laws I am going to reveal; ye, hear which and how they are.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: These Bodhisattvas, immense, inconceivable and beyond measure, endowed with magic power, wisdom, and learning, have progressed in knowledge for many kotis of Æons.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: It is I who have brought them to maturity for enlightenment, and it is in my field that they have their abode; by me alone have they been brought to maturity; these Bodhisattvas are my sons.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: All have devoted themselves to a hermit life and are assiduous in shunning places of bustle; they walk detached, these sons of mine, following my precepts in their lofty course.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: They dwell in the domain of ether, in the lower portion of the field, those heroes who, unwearied, are striving day and night to attain superior knowledge.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: All strenuous, of good memory, unshaken in the immense strength of their intelligence, those serene sages preach the law, all radiant, as being my sons.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: Since the time when I reached this superior (or foremost) enlightenment, at the town of Gayâ, at the foot of the tree, and put in motion the allsurpassing wheel of the law, I have brought to maturity all of them for superior enlightenment.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: These words I here speak are faultless, really true; believe me, all of you who hear me: verily, I have reached superior enlightenment, and it is by me alone that all have been brought to maturity.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: When thou wert born in Kapilavastu, the home of the Sâkyas, thou didst leave it and reach enlightenment at the town of Gayâ. That is a short time ago, O Lord of the world.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: And now thou hast so great a crowd of followers, these sages who for many kotis of Æons have fulfilled their duties, stood firm in magic power, unshaken, well disciplined, accomplished in the might of wisdom;

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: These, who are untainted as the lotus is by water; who to-day have flocked hither after rending the earth, and are standing all with joined hands, respectful and strong in memory, the sons of the Master of the world.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: How will these Bodhisattvas believe this great wonder? Expel (all) doubt, tell the cause, and show how the matter reallv is.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: It is as if there were some man, a young man with black hair, twenty years old or somewhat more, who presented as his sons some centenarians,

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: And the latter, covered with wrinkles and grey-haired, declared the (young) man to be their father. But such (a young man) never having sons of such appearance, it would be difficult to believe, O Lord of the world, that they were sons to so young a man.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: In the same manner, O Lord, we are unable to conceive how these numerous Bodhisattvas of good memory and excelling in wisdom, who have been well instructed during thousands of kotis of Æons;

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: Who are firm, of keen intelligence, lovely and agreeable to sight, free from hesitation in the decisions on law, praised by the Leaders of the world;

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: Who in freedom live in the wood; who unattached in the element of ether constantly display their energy, who are the sons of Sugata striving after this Buddha-ground;

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: How will this be believed when the Leader of the world shall be completely extinct? After hearing it from the Lord's own mouth we shall never more feel any doubt.

title: ISSUING OF BODHISATTVAS FROM THE GAPS OF THE EARTH.
text: May Bodhisattvas never come to grief by having doubt on this head. Grant us, O Lord, a truthful account how these Bodhisattvas have been brought to maturity by thee.

title: DURATION OF LIFE OF THE TATHÂGATA.
text: An inconceivable number of thousands of kotis of Æons, never to be measured, is it since I reached superior (or first) enlightenment and never ceased to teach the law.

title: DURATION OF LIFE OF THE TATHÂGATA.
text: I roused many Bodhisattvas and established them in Buddha-knowledge. I brought myriads of kotis of beings, endless, to full ripeness in many kotis of Æons.

title: DURATION OF LIFE OF THE TATHÂGATA.
text: I show the place of extinction, I reveal to (all) beings a device to educate them, albeit I do not become extinct at the time, and in this very place continue preaching the law.

title: DURATION OF LIFE OF THE TATHÂGATA.
text: There I rule myself as well as all beings, I. But men of perverted minds, in their delusion, do not see me standing there.

title: DURATION OF LIFE OF THE TATHÂGATA.
text: In the opinion that my body is completely extinct, they pay worship, in many ways, to the relics, but me they see not. They feel (however) a certain aspiration by which their mind becomes right.

title: DURATION OF LIFE OF THE TATHÂGATA.
text: When such upright (or pious), mild, and gentle creatures leave off their bodies, then I assemble the crowd of disciples and show myself here on the Gridhrakûta.

title: DURATION OF LIFE OF THE TATHÂGATA.
text: And then I speak thus to them, in this very place: I was not completely extinct at that time; it was but a device of mine, monks; repeatedly am I born in the world of the living.

title: DURATION OF LIFE OF THE TATHÂGATA.
text: Honoured by other beings, I show them my superior enlightenment, but you would not obey my word, unless the Lord of the world enter Nirvâna.

title: DURATION OF LIFE OF THE TATHÂGATA.
text: I see how the creatures are afflicted, but I do not show them my proper being. Let them first have an aspiration to see me; then I will reveal to them the true law.

title: DURATION OF LIFE OF THE TATHÂGATA.
text: Such has always been my firm resolve during an inconceivable number of thousands of kotis of Æons, and I have not left this Gridhrakûta for other abodes.

title: DURATION OF LIFE OF THE TATHÂGATA.
text: And when creatures behold this world and imagine that it is burning, even then my Buddhafield is teeming with gods and men.

title: DURATION OF LIFE OF THE TATHÂGATA.
text: They dispose of manifold amusements, kotis of pleasure gardens, palaces, and aerial cars; (this field) is embellished by hills of gems and by trees abounding with blossoms and fruits.

title: DURATION OF LIFE OF THE TATHÂGATA.
text: And aloft gods are striking musical instruments and pouring a rain of Mandâras by which they are covering me, the disciples and other sages who are striving after enlightenment.

title: DURATION OF LIFE OF THE TATHÂGATA.
text: So is my field here, everlasti.ngly; but others fancy that it is burning; in their view this world is most terrific, wretched, replete with number of woes.

title: DURATION OF LIFE OF THE TATHÂGATA.
text: Ay, many kotis of years they may pass without ever having mentioned my name, the law, or my congregation. That is the fruit of sinful deeds.

title: DURATION OF LIFE OF THE TATHÂGATA.
text: But when mild and gentle beings are born in this world of men, they immediately see me revealing the law, owing to their good works.

title: DURATION OF LIFE OF THE TATHÂGATA.
text: I never speak to them of the infinitude of my action. Therefore, I am, properly, existing since long, and yet declare: The Ginas are rare (or precious).

title: DURATION OF LIFE OF THE TATHÂGATA.
text: Such is the glorious power of my wisdom that knows no limit, and the duration of my life is as long as an endless period; I have acquired it after previously following a due course.

title: DURATION OF LIFE OF THE TATHÂGATA.
text: Feel no doubt concerning it, O sages, and leave off all uncertainty: the word I here pronounce is really true; my word is never false.

title: DURATION OF LIFE OF THE TATHÂGATA.
text: For even as that physician skilled in devices, for the sake of his sons whose notions were perverted, said that he had died although he was still alive, and even as no sensible man, would charge that physician with falsehood;

title: DURATION OF LIFE OF THE TATHÂGATA.
text: So am I the father of the world, the Self born, the Healer, the Protector of all creatures. Knowing them to be perverted, infatuated, and ignorant I teach final rest, myself not being at rest.

title: DURATION OF LIFE OF THE TATHÂGATA.
text: What reason should I have to continually manifest myself? When men become unbelieving, unwise, ignorant, careless, fond of sensual pleasures, and from thoughtlessness run into misfortune,

title: DURATION OF LIFE OF THE TATHÂGATA.
text: Then I, who know the course of the world, declare: I am so and so, (and consider): How can I incline them to enlightenment? how can they become partakers of the Buddha-laws?

title: OF PIETY.
text: Wonderful is the law which the Sugata has expounded, the law we never heard before; how great the majesty of the Leaders is, and how infinite the duration of their life!

title: OF PIETY.
text: And on hearing such a law imparted by the Sugata from face to face, thousands of kotis of creatures, the genuine sons of the Leader of the world, have been pervaded with gladness.

title: OF PIETY.
text: Some have reached the point of supreme enlightenment from whence there is no return, others are standing on the lower stage; some have reached the standpoint of having an unhampered view, and others have obtained thousands of kotis of Dhâranis.

title: OF PIETY.
text: There are others, (as) atoms, who have reached supreme Buddha-knowledge. Some, again, will after eight births become Ginas seeing the infinite.

title: OF PIETY.
text: Among those who hear this law from the Master, some will obtain enlightenment and see the truth after four births, others after three, others after two.

title: OF PIETY.
text: Some among them will become all-knowing after one birth, in the next following existence. Such will be the perfect result of learning the duration of life of the Chief.

title: OF PIETY.
text: Innumerable, countless as the atoms of the eight fields, are the kotis of beings who by hearing this law have conceived the idea of superior enlightenment.

title: OF PIETY.
text: Such is the effect produced by the great Seer, when he reveals this Buddha-state that is endless and has no limit, which is as immense as the element of ether.

title: OF PIETY.
text: Many thousand kotis of angels, Indras, and Brahma-angels, like the sands of the Ganges, have flocked hither from thousands of kotis of distant fields and have poured a rain of Mandairavas.

title: OF PIETY.
text: They move in the sky like birds, and strew fragrant powder of sandal and agallochum, to cover ceremoniously the Chief of Ginas withal.

title: OF PIETY.
text: High aloft tymbals without being struck emit sweet sounds; thousands of kotis of white cloth whirl down upon the Chiefs.

title: OF PIETY.
text: Thousands of kotis of jewel censers of costly incense move of their own accord on every side to honour the mighty Lord of the world.

title: OF PIETY.
text: Innumerable wise Bodhisattvas hold myriads of kotis of umbrellas, elevated and made of noble jewels, like chaplets, up to the Brahma-world.

title: OF PIETY.
text: The sons of Sugata, in their great joy, have attached beautiful triumphal streamers at the top of the banner staffs in honour of the Leaders whom they celebrate in thousands of stanzas.

title: OF PIETY.
text: Such a marvellous, extraordinary, prodigious, splendid phenomenon, O Leader, is being displayed by all those beings who are gladdened by the exposition of the duration of life (of the Tathâgata).

title: OF PIETY.
text: Grand is the matter now (occurring) in the ten points of space, and (great) the sound raised by the Leaders; thousands of kotis of living beings are refreshed and gifted with virtue for enlightenment.

title: OF PIETY.
text: Let a man who is seeking after this knowledge, superior Buddha-knowledge, undertake to practise in this world the five perfect virtues;

title: OF PIETY.
text: Let him, during eight thousand kotis of complete Æons, continue giving repeated alms to Buddhas and disciples;

title: OF PIETY.
text: Regaling Pratyekabuddhas and kotis of Bodhisattvas by giving meat, food and drink, clothing and lodging;

title: OF PIETY.
text: Let him build on earth refuges and monasteries of sandal-wood, and pleasant convent gardens provided with walks;

title: OF PIETY.
text: Let him after so bestowing gifts, various and diversified, during thousands of kotis of Æons, direct his mind to enlightenment;

title: OF PIETY.
text: Let him then, for the sake of Buddhaknowledge, keep unbroken the pure moral precepts which have been recommended by the perfect Buddhas and acknowledged by the wise;

title: OF PIETY.
text: Let him further develop the virtue of forbearance, be steady in the stage of meekness [i.e. of a monk under training.], be constant, of good memory, and patiently endure many censures;

title: OF PIETY.
text: Let him, moreover, for the sake of Buddha-knowledge, bear the contemptuous words of unbelievers who are rooted in pride;

title: OF PIETY.
text: Let him, always zealous, strenuous, studious, of good memory, without any other pre-occupation in his mind, practise meditation, during kotis of.Æons;

title: OF PIETY.
text: Let him, whether living in the forest or entering upon a vagrant life [i.e. a Yogin, a contemplative mystic.], go about, avoiding sloth and torpor, for kotis of Æons;

title: OF PIETY.
text: Let him as a philosopher, a great philosopher who finds his delight in meditation, in concentration of mind, pass eight thousand kotis of Æons;

title: OF PIETY.
text: Let him energetically pursue enlightenment with the thought of his reaching all-knowingness, and so arrive at the highest degree of meditation;

title: OF PIETY.
text: Then the merit accruing to those who practise the virtues oft described, during thousands of kotis of Æons,

title: OF PIETY.
text: (Is less than that of) a man or a woman who, on hearing the duration of my life, for a single moment believes in it; this merit is endless.

title: OF PIETY.
text: He who renouncing doubt, vacillation, and misgiving shall believe even for a short moment, shall obtain such a reward.

title: OF PIETY.
text: The Bodhisattvas also,who have practised those virtues during kotis of Æons, will not be startled at hearing of this inconceivably long life of mine.

title: OF PIETY.
text: They will bow their heads (and think): 'May I also in future become such a one and release kotis of living beings!

title: OF PIETY.
text: 'As the Lord Sâkyamuni, the Lion of the Sakya race, after he had occupied his seat on the terrace of enlightenment, raised his lion's roar;

title: OF PIETY.
text: 'So may I in future be sitting on the terrace of enlightenment, honoured by all mortals, to teach so long a life!'

title: OF PIETY.
text: Those who are possessed of firmness of intention and have learnt the principles, will understand the mystery and feel no uncertaint.

title: OF PIETY.
text: An immense mass of merit, as I have repeatedly mentioned, shall be his who, after the complete extinction of the Leader of men, shall keep this Sûtra.

title: OF PIETY.
text: He will have paid worship to me, and built Stûpas of relics, made of precious substances, variegated, beautiful, and splendid;

title: OF PIETY.
text: In height coming up to the Brahma-world, with rows of umbrellas, great in circumference gorgeous, and decorated with triumphal streamers;

title: OF PIETY.
text: Resounding with the clear ring of bells, and decorated with silk bands, while jingles moved by the wind form another ornament at (the shrines of) Gina relics.

title: OF PIETY.
text: He will have shown great honour to them by flowers, perfumes, and ointments ; by music, clothes, and the repeated (sound of) tymbals.

title: OF PIETY.
text: He will have sweet musical instruments struck at those relics, and lamps with scented oil kept burning all around.

title: OF PIETY.
text: He who at the period of depravation shall keep and teach this Sûtra, he will have paid me such an infinitely varied worship.

title: OF PIETY.
text: He has built many kotis of excellent monasteries of sandal-wood, with thirty-two pinnacles, and eight terraces high;

title: OF PIETY.
text: Provided with couches, with food hard and soft; furnished with excellent curtains, and having cells by thousands.

title: OF PIETY.
text: He has given hermitages and walks embellished by flower-gardens; many elegant objects of various forms and variegated.

title: OF PIETY.
text: He has shown manifold worship to the host of disciples in my presence, he who, after my extinction, shall keep this Sûtra.

title: OF PIETY.
text: Let one be ever so good in disposition, much greater merit will he obtain who shall keep or write this Sûtra.

title: OF PIETY.
text: Let a man cause this to be written and have it well put together in a volume; let him always worship the volume with flowers, garlands, ointments.

title: OF PIETY.
text: Let him constantly place near it a lamp filled with scented oil, along with full-blown lotuses and suitable' oblations of Michelia Champaka.

title: OF PIETY.
text: The man who pays such worship to the books will produce a mass of merit which is not to be measured.

title: OF PIETY.
text: Even as there is no measure of the element of ether, in none of the ten directions, so there is no measure of this mass of merit.

title: OF PIETY.
text: How much more will this be the case with one who is patient, meek, devoted, moral, studious, and addicted to meditation;

title: OF PIETY.
text: Who is not irascible, not treacherous, reverential towards the sanctuary, always humble towards monks, not conceited, nor neglectful;

title: OF PIETY.
text: Sensible and wise, not angry when he is asked a question; who, full of compassion for living beings, gives such instruction as suits them.

title: OF PIETY.
text: If there be such a man who (at the same time) keeps this Sûtra, he will possess a mass of merit that cannot be measured.

title: OF PIETY.
text: If one meets such a man as here described, a keeper of this Sûtra, one should do homage to him.

title: OF PIETY.
text: One should present him with divine flowers, cover him with divine clothes, and bow the head to salute his feet, in the conviction of his being a Tathâgata.

title: OF PIETY.
text: And at the sight of such a man one may directly make the reflection that he is going towards the foot of the tree to arrive at superior, blessed enlightenment for the weal of all the world, including the gods.

title: OF PIETY.
text: And wherever such a sage is walking, standing, sitting, or lying down; wherever the hero pronounces were it but a single stanza from this Sûtra;

title: OF PIETY.
text: There one should build a Stûpa for the most high of men, a splendid, beautiful (Stûpa), dedicated to the Lord Buddha, the Chief, and then worship it in manifold ways.

title: OF PIETY.
text: That spot of the earth has been enjoyed by myself; there have I walked myself, and there have I been sitting; where that son of Buddha has stayed, there I am.

title: INDICATION OF THE MERITORIOUSNESS OF JOYFUL ACCEPTANCE.
text: How great will be the merit of him who, after the extinction of the great Hero, shall hear this exalted Sûtra and joyfully accept it?

title: INDICATION OF THE MERITORIOUSNESS OF JOYFUL ACCEPTANCE.
text: part, not the 1/100,000, not the 1/10,000,000 not the 1/1000,000,000 not the 1/1000 x 10,000,000 not the 1/100,000 x 10,000,000, not the 1/100,000 x 10,000 x 10,000,000 part; it admits of no calculation, no counting, no reckoning, no comparison, no approximation, no secret teaching. So immense, incalculable, Agita, is the merit which a person, ranking the fiftieth in the series of the tradition of the law, produces by joyfully accepting, were it but a single stanza, a single word, from this Dharmaparyâya; how much more then (will) he (produce), Agita, who hears this Dharmaparyâya in my presence and then joyfully accepts it? I declare, Agita, that his accumulation of merit shall be even more immense, more incalculable.

title: INDICATION OF THE MERITORIOUSNESS OF JOYFUL ACCEPTANCE.
text: Listen how great the merit is of one who, the fiftieth in the series (of tradition), hears a single stanza from this Sûtra and with placid mind joyfully adopts it.

title: INDICATION OF THE MERITORIOUSNESS OF JOYFUL ACCEPTANCE.
text: Suppose there is a man in the habit of giving alms to myriads of kotis of beings, whom I have herebefore indicated by way of comparison'; all of them he satisfies during eighty years.

title: INDICATION OF THE MERITORIOUSNESS OF JOYFUL ACCEPTANCE.
text: Then seeing that old age has approached for them, that their brow is wrinkled and their head grey (he thinks): Alas, how all beings come to decay! Let me therefore admonish them by (speaking of) the law.

title: INDICATION OF THE MERITORIOUSNESS OF JOYFUL ACCEPTANCE.
text: He teaches them the law here on earth and points to the state of Nirvana hereafter. 'All existences' (he says) 'are like a mirage; hasten to become disgusted with all existence.'

title: INDICATION OF THE MERITORIOUSNESS OF JOYFUL ACCEPTANCE.
text: All creatures, by hearing the law from that charitable person, become at once Arhats, free from imperfections, and living their last life.

title: INDICATION OF THE MERITORIOUSNESS OF JOYFUL ACCEPTANCE.
text: Much more merit than by that person will be acquired by him who through unbroken tradition shall hear were it but a single stanza and joyfully receive it. The mass of merit of the former is not even so much as a small particle of the latter's.

title: INDICATION OF THE MERITORIOUSNESS OF JOYFUL ACCEPTANCE.
text: So great will be one's merit, endless, immeasurable, owing to one's hearing merely a single stanza, in regular tradition; how much more then if one hears from face to face!

title: INDICATION OF THE MERITORIOUSNESS OF JOYFUL ACCEPTANCE.
text: And if somebody exhorts were it but a single creature and says: Go, hear the law, for this Sûtra is rare in many myriads of kotis of Æons;

title: INDICATION OF THE MERITORIOUSNESS OF JOYFUL ACCEPTANCE.
text: And if the creature so exhorted should hear the Sûtra even for a moment, hark what fruit is to result from that action. He shall never have a mouth disease;

title: INDICATION OF THE MERITORIOUSNESS OF JOYFUL ACCEPTANCE.
text: His tongue is never sore; his teeth shall never fall out, never be black, yellow, unequal; his lips never become loathsome;

title: INDICATION OF THE MERITORIOUSNESS OF JOYFUL ACCEPTANCE.
text: His face is not wry, nor lean, nor long; his nose not flat; it is well-shaped, as well as his forehead, teeth, lips, and round face.

title: INDICATION OF THE MERITORIOUSNESS OF JOYFUL ACCEPTANCE.
text: His aspect is ever pleasant to men; his mouth is never fetid, it constantly emits a smell sweet as the lotus.

title: INDICATION OF THE MERITORIOUSNESS OF JOYFUL ACCEPTANCE.
text: If some wise man, to hear this Sûtra, goes from his home to a monastery and there listen, were it but for a single moment, with a placid mind, hear what results from it.

title: INDICATION OF THE MERITORIOUSNESS OF JOYFUL ACCEPTANCE.
text: His body is very fair; he drives with horsecarriages, that wise man, and is mounted on elevated carriages drawn by elephants and variegated with gems.

title: INDICATION OF THE MERITORIOUSNESS OF JOYFUL ACCEPTANCE.
text: He possesses litters covered with ornaments and carried by numerous men. Such is the blessed fruit of his going to hear preaching.

title: INDICATION OF THE MERITORIOUSNESS OF JOYFUL ACCEPTANCE.
text: Owing to the performance of that pious work he shall, when sitting in the assembly there, obtain seats of Indra, seats of Brahma, seats of kings.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: Hear from me what good qualities shall belong to him who unhesitatingly and undismayed shall preach this Sûtra to the congregated assembly.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: First, then, his eye (or, organ of vision) shall possess eight hundred good qualities by which it shall be correct, clear, and untroubled.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He shall see the Meru and Sumeru, all the horizon and other mountains, as well as the seas.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He, the hero, sees all, downward to the Avîki and upward to the extremity of existence. Such is his carnal eye.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: But he has not yet got the divine eye, it having not yet been produced in him; such as here described is the range of his carnal eye.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: The organ of hearing of such a person becomes (or, is) cleared and perfect, though as yet it be natural; by it he perceives the various sounds, without any exception, in this world.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He perceives the sounds of elephants, horses, cars, cows, goats, and sheep; of noisy kettle-drums, tabours, lutes, flutes, Vallaki-lutes.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He can hear singing, lovely and sweet, and, at the same time, is constant enough not to allow himself to be beguiled by it; he perceives the sounds of kotis of men, whatever and wherever they are speaking.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He, moreover, always hears the voice of gods and Nâgas; he hears the tunes, sweet and affecting, of song, as well as the voices of men and women, boys and girls.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He hears the cries of the denizens of mountains and glens; the tender notes of Kalavinkas, cuckoos, pea fowls, pheasants, and other birds.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He also (hears) the heart-rending cries of those who are suffering pains in the hells, and the yells uttered by the Spirits, vexed as they are by the difficulty to get food;

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: Likewise the different cries produced by the demons and the inhabitants of the ocean. All these sounds the preacher is able to hear from his place on earth, without being overpowered by them.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: From where he is stationed here on the earth he also hears the different and multifarious sounds through which the inhabitants of the realm of brutes are conversing with each other.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He apprehends all the sounds, without any exception, whereby the numerous angels living in the Brahma-world, the Akanishthas and Âbhâsvaras, call one another.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He likewise always hears the sound which the monks on earth are raising when engaged in reading, and when preaching the law to congregations, after having taken orders under the command of the Sugatas.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: And when the Bodhisattvas here on earth have a reading together and raise their voices in the general synods, he hears them severally.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: The Bodhisattva who preaches this Stara shall, at one time, also hear the perfect law 2 that the Lord Buddha, the tamer of men, announces to the assemblies.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: The numerous sounds produced by all beings in the triple world, in this field, within and without, (downward) to the Avîki and upward to the extremity of existence, are heard by him.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: (In short), he perceives the voices of all beings, his ear being open. Being in the possession of his six senses, he will discern the different sources (of sound), and that while his organ of hearing is the natural one;

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: The divine ear is not yet operating in him; his ear continues in its natural state. Such as here told are the good qualities belonging to the wise man who shall be a keeper of this Sûtra.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: His organ of smell is quite correct, and he perceives the manifold and various smells, good or bad, which exist in this world;

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: The fragrance of the great-flowered jasmine, Arabian jasmine, Xanthochymus, sandal, agallochum, of several blossoms and fruits.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He likewise perceives the smells exhaled by men, women, boys, and girls, at a considerable distance, and by the smell he knows where they are.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He recognises emperors, rulers of armies, governors of provinces, as well as royal princes and ministers, and all the ladies of the harem by their (peculiar) scent.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: It is by the odour that the Bodhisattva discovers sundry jewels of things, such as are found on the earth and such as serve as jewels for women.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: That Bodhisattva likewise knows by the odour the various kinds of ornament that women use for their body, robes, wreaths, and ointments.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: The wise man who keeps this exalted Sûtra recognises, by the power of a good-smelling organ, a woman standing, sitting, or lying; he discovers wanton sport and magic power.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He perceives at once where he stands, the fragrance of scented oils, and the different odours of flowers and fruits, and thereby knows from what source the odour proceeds.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: The discriminating man recognises by the odour the numerous sandal-trees in full blossom in the glens of the mountains, as well as all creatures dwelling there.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: All the beings living within the compass of the horizon or dwelling in the depth of the sea or in the bosom of the earth the discriminating man knows how to distinguish from the (peculiar) smell.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He discerns the gods and demons, and the daughters of demons; he discovers the sports of demons and their luxury. Such, indeed, is the power of his organ of smell.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: By the smell he tracks the abodes of the quadrupeds in the woods, lions, tigers, elephants, snakes, buffaloes, cows, gayals.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He infers from the odour, whether the child that women, languid from pregnancy, bear in the womb be a boy or a girl.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He can discern if a woman is big with a dead child; he discerns if she is subject to throes, and, further, if a woman, the pains being removed, shall be delivered of a healthy boy.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He guesses the various designs of men, he smells (so to say) an air of design; he finds out the odour of passionate, wicked, hypocritical, or quiet persons.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: That Bodhisattva by the scent smells treasures hidden in the ground, money, gold, bullion, silver, chests, and metal pots.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: Necklaces of two sorts, gems, pearls, nice priceless jewels he knows by the scent, as well as things priceless and brilliant in general.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: That great man from his very place on earth smells the flowers here above (in the sky) with the gods, such as Mandâravas, Mañgûshakas, and those growing on the coral tree.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: By the power of his organ of smell he, without leaving his stand on earth, perceives how and whose are the aerial cars, of lofty, low, and middling size, and other brilliant forms shooting (through the firmament).

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He likewise finds out the paradise, the gods (in the hall) of Sudharmâ and in the most glorious palace of Vaigayanta, and the angels who there are diverting themselves.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He perceives, here on earth, an air of them; by the scent he knows the angels, and where each of them is acting, standing, listening, or walking.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: That Bodhisattva tracks by the scent the houris who are decorated with many flowers, decked with wreaths and ornaments and in full attire; he knows wherever they are dallying or staying at the time.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: By smell he apprehends the gods, Brahmas, and Brahmakâyas moving on aerial cars aloft, upwards to the extremity of existence; he knows whether they are absorbed in meditation or have risen from it.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He perceives the Âbhâsvara angels falling (and shooting) and appearing, even those that he never saw before. Such is the organ of smell of the Bodhisattva who keeps this Sûtra.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: The Bodhisattva also recognises all monks under the rule of the Sugata, who are strenuously engaged in their walks and find their delight in their lessons and reading.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: Intelligent as he is, he discerns those among the sons of Gina who are disciples and those who used to live at the foot of trees, and he knows that the monk so and so is staying in such and such a place.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: The Bodhisattva knows by the odour whether other Bodhisattvas are of good memory, meditative, delighting in their lessons and reading, and assiduous in preaching to congregations.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: In whatever point of space the Sugata, the great Seer, so benign and bounteous, reveals the law in the midst of the crowd of attending disciples, the Bodhisattva by the odour recognises him as the Lord of the universe.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: Staying on earth, the Bodhisattva also perceives those beings who hear the law and rejoice at it, and the whole assembly of the Gina.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: Such is the power of his organ of smell. Yet it is not the divine organ he possesses, but (the natural one) prior to the perfect, divine faculty of smell.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: His organ of taste is most excellent, and he will never relish anything of inferior flavour; the flavours are no sooner put on his tongue than they become divine and possessed of a divine taste.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He has a tender voice and delivers sweet words, pleasant to hear, agreeable, charming; in the midst of the assembly lie is used to speak with a melodious and deep voice.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: And whosoever hears him when he is delivering a sermon with myriads of kotis of examples, feels a great joy and shows him an immense veneration.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: The gods, Nâgas, demons, and goblins always long to see him, and respectfully listen to his preaching. All those good qualities are his.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: If he would, he might make his voice heard by the whole of this world; his voice is (so) fine, sweet, deep, tender, and winning.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: The emperors on earth, along with their children and wives, go to him with the purpose of honouring him, and listen all the time to his sermon with joined hands.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He is constantly followed by goblins, crowds of Nâgas, Gandharvas, imps, male and female, who honour, respect, and worship him.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: Brahma himself becomes his obedient servant; the gods Îsvara and Mahesvara, as well as Indra and the numerous heavenly nymphs, approach him.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: And the Buddhas, benign and merciful for the world, along with their disciples, hearing his voice, protect him by showing their face, and feel satisfaction in hearing him preaching.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: His body becomes thoroughly pure, clear as if consisting of lapis lazuli; he who keeps this sublime Sûtra is always a pleasant sight for (all) creatures.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: As on the surface of a mirror an image is seen, so on his body this world. Being self-born, he sees no other beings. Such is the perfectness of his body.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: Indeed, all beings who are in this world, men, gods, demons, goblins, the inhabitants of hell, the spirits, and the brute creation are seen reflected on that body.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: The aerial cars of the gods up to the extremity of existence, the rocks, the ridge of the horizon, the Himâlaya, Sumeru, and great Meru, all are seen on that body.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He also sees the Buddhas on his body, along with the disciples and other sons of Buddha; likewise the Bodhisattvas who lead a solitary life, and those who preach the law to congregations.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: Such is the perfectness of his body, though he has not yet obtained a divine body; the natural property of his body is such.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: His mental organ is perfect, lucid, right, and untroubled. By it he finds out the various laws, low, high, and mean.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: On hearing the contents of a single stanza, the wise man catches the manifold significations (hidden) in it, and he is able for a month, four months, or even a year to go on expounding both its conventional and its true sense.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: And the beings living in this world, within or without, gods, men, demons, goblins, Nâgas, brutes,

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: The beings stationed in any of the six conditions of existence, all their thoughts the sage knows instantaneously. These are the advantages of keeping this Sûtra.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He also hears the holy sound of the law which the Buddha, marked with a hundred blessed signs, preaches all over the world, and he catches what the Buddha speaks.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He reflects much on the supreme law, and is in the wont of constantly dilating upon it; he is never hesitating. These are the advantages of keeping this Sûtra.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He knows the connections and knots; he discerns in all laws contrarieties; he knows the meaning and the interpretations, and expounds them according to his knowledge.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: The Sûtra which since so long a time has been expounded by the ancient Masters of the world is the law which he, never flinching, is always preaching in the assembly.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: Such is the mental organ of him who keeps or reads this Sûtra; he has not yet the knowledge of emancipation, but one that precedes it.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF A RELIGIOUS PREACHER.
text: He who keeps this Sûtra of the Sugata stands on the stage of a master; he may preach to all creatures and is skilful in kotis of interpretations.

title: SADÂPARIBHÛTA.
text: I remember a past period, when king Bhîshmasvara, the Gina, lived, very mighty, and revered by gods and men, the leader of men, gods, goblins, and giants.

title: SADÂPARIBHÛTA.
text: At the time succeeding the complete extinction of that Gina, when the decay of the true law was far advanced, there was a monk, a Bodhisattva, called by the name of Sadâparibhûta.

title: SADÂPARIBHÛTA.
text: Other monks and nuns who did not believe but in what they saw, he would approach (and say): I never am to contemn you, for you observe the course leading to supreme enlightenment.

title: SADÂPARIBHÛTA.
text: It was his wont always to utter those words, which brought him but abuse and taunts from their part. At the time when his death was impending he heard this Sûtra.

title: SADÂPARIBHÛTA.
text: The sage, then, did not expire; he resolved upon a very long life, and promulgated this Sûtra under the rule of that leader.

title: SADÂPARIBHÛTA.
text: And those many (persons) who only acknowledged the evidence of sensual perception were by him brought to full ripeness for enlightenment. Then, disappearing from that place, he propitiated thousands of kotis of Buddhas.

title: SADÂPARIBHÛTA.
text: Owing to the successive good actions performed by him, and to his constantly promulgating this Sûtra, that son of Gina reached enlightenment. That Bodhisattva then is myself, Sâkyamuni.

title: SADÂPARIBHÛTA.
text: And those persons who only believed in perception by the senses, those monks, nuns, male and female lay devotees who by the sage were admonished of enlightenment,

title: SADÂPARIBHÛTA.
text: And who have seen many kotis of Buddhas, are the monks here before me,-no less than five hundred,-nuns, and female lay devotees.

title: SADÂPARIBHÛTA.
text: All of them have been by me brought to complete ripeness, and after my extinction they will all, full of wisdom, keep this Sûtra.

title: SADÂPARIBHÛTA.
text: Not once in many, inconceivably many kotis of Æons has such a Sûtra as this been heard. There are, indeed, hundreds of kotis of Buddhas, but they do not elucidate this Sûtra.

title: SADÂPARIBHÛTA.
text: Therefore let one who has heard this law exposed by the Self-born himself, and who has repeatedly propitiated him, promulgate this Sûtra after my extinction in this world.

title: CONCEPTION OF THE TRANSCENDENT POWER OF THE TATHÂGATAS.
text: Inconceivable is the power to promote the weal of the world possessed by those who, firmly established in transcendent knowledge, by means of their unlimited sight display their magic faculty in order to gladden all living beings on earth.

title: CONCEPTION OF THE TRANSCENDENT POWER OF THE TATHÂGATAS.
text: They extend their tongue over the whole world, darting thousands of beams to the astonishment of those to whom this effect of magic is displayed and who are making for supreme enlightenment.

title: CONCEPTION OF THE TRANSCENDENT POWER OF THE TATHÂGATAS.
text: The Buddhas made a noise of expectoration and of snapping the fingers, (and by it) called the attention of the whole world, of all parts of the world in the ten directions of space.

title: CONCEPTION OF THE TRANSCENDENT POWER OF THE TATHÂGATAS.
text: Those and other miraculous qualities they display in their benevolence and compassion (with the view) that the creatures, gladly excited at the time, may (also) keep the Sûtra after the complete extinction of the Sugata.

title: CONCEPTION OF THE TRANSCENDENT POWER OF THE TATHÂGATAS.
text: Even if I continued for thousands of kotis of Æons speaking the praise of those sons of Sugata who shall keep this eminent Sûtra after thc extinction of the Leader of the world,

title: CONCEPTION OF THE TRANSCENDENT POWER OF THE TATHÂGATAS.
text: I should not have terminated the enumeration of their qualities; inconceivable as the qualities of infinite space are the merits of those who constantly keep this holy Sûtra.

title: CONCEPTION OF THE TRANSCENDENT POWER OF THE TATHÂGATAS.
text: They behold me as well as these chiefs, and the Leader of the world now extinct; (they behold) all these numerous Bodhisattvas and the four classes.

title: CONCEPTION OF THE TRANSCENDENT POWER OF THE TATHÂGATAS.
text: Such a one now here propitiates me and all these leaders, as well as the extinct chief of Ginas and the others in every quarter.

title: CONCEPTION OF THE TRANSCENDENT POWER OF THE TATHÂGATAS.
text: The future and past Buddhas stationed in the ten points of space will all be seen and worshipped by him who keeps this Sûtra.

title: CONCEPTION OF THE TRANSCENDENT POWER OF THE TATHÂGATAS.
text: He who keeps this Sûtra, the veritable law, will fathom the mystery of the highest man; will soon comprehend what truth it was that was arrived at on the terrace of enlightenment.

title: CONCEPTION OF THE TRANSCENDENT POWER OF THE TATHÂGATAS.
text: The quickness of his apprehension will be unlimited; like the wind he will nowhere meet impediments; he knows the purport and interpretation of the law, he who keeps this exalted Sûtra.

title: CONCEPTION OF THE TRANSCENDENT POWER OF THE TATHÂGATAS.
text: He will, after some reflection, always find out the connection of the Sûtras spoken by the leaders; even after the complete extinction of the leader he will grasp the real meaning of the Sûtras.

title: CONCEPTION OF THE TRANSCENDENT POWER OF THE TATHÂGATAS.
text: He resembles the moon and the sun; he illuminates all around him, and while roaming the earth in different directions he rouses many Bodhisattvas.

title: CONCEPTION OF THE TRANSCENDENT POWER OF THE TATHÂGATAS.
text: The wise Bodhisattvas who, after hearing the enumeration of such advantages, shall keep this Sûtra after my complete extinction will doubtless reach enlightenment.

title: SPELLS.
text: His head shall be split into seven pieces, like a sprout of Symplocos Racemosa, who after hearing this spell would attack a preacher.

title: SPELLS.
text: He shall go the way of parricides and matricides, who would attack a preacher.

title: SPELLS.
text: He shall go the way of oil-millers and sesamum-pounders, who would attack a preacher.

title: SPELLS.
text: He shall go the way of those who use false weights and measures, who would attack a preacher.

title: ANCIENT DEVOTION OF BHAISHAGYARÂGA.
text: This, O exalted king, is the walk in which I have acquired meditation; I have achieved a heroical feat, fulfilled a great vote by sacrificing my own dear body.

title: ANCIENT DEVOTION OF BHAISHAGYARÂGA.
text: O thou whose face is so spotless and bright; thou, king and sage! How thy lustre sparkles in all quarters! After having anciently paid thee homage, O Sugata, I now come again to behold thee, O Lord.

title: CHAPTER CALLED THAT OF THE ALL-SIDED ONE, CONTAINING A DESCRIPTION OF THE TRANSFORMATIONS OF AVALOKITESVARA.
text: Kitradhvaga asked Akshayamati the following question: For what reason, son of Gina, is Avalokitesvara (so) called?
